docs.lead_paragraph: Mo Vaughn wasn't in the Boston Red Sox spring training camp today. Roger Clemens wasn't there, either. But then neither was Ted Williams, nor Babe Ruth for that matter. Let it be said that the Red Sox, even without each of the last three players, did finish first in their league or division. And someday maybe they will finish first again without Vaughn. But this year is not likely to be that day.
docs.abstract: Article describes scene at Boston Red Sox spring training camp; photo (M)

headline.main: BASEBALL: Invisible Man on First; Boston Let Mo Vaughn Go, but Who Will Replace Him?

docs.lead_paragraph: Mo Vaughin refused Boston's request that he undergo an alcohol evaluation, saying yesterday that the Red Sox were using his arrest on drunken driving charges as an excuse not to sign him.
docs.abstract: Mo Vaughin refuses Boston Red Sox's request that he undergo alcohol evaluation, saying that team is using his arrest on drunken driving charges as an excuse not to sign him (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: BOSTON Landmark Pact For Garciaparra Nomar Garciaparra, a unanimous choice as the American League rookie of the year, agreed yesterday to a landmark $23.25 million, five-year contract with the Red Sox that could escalate to $44.25 million if the team exercises two option years. The deal is unprecedented for a player who has been in the major leagues for little more than a season. The deal for the 24-year-old shortstop also dwarfs that of the National League rookie of the year Scott Rolen, who agreed last week to a $10 million, four-year contract with the Phillies.
docs.abstract: Nomar Garciaparra, 1997 American League rookie of year, agrees to landmark $23.25 million, five-year contract with Boston Red Sox (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Red Sox first baseman Mo Vaughn launched a campaign yesterday to redeem his image after his arrest last weekend on drunken driving charges. In his first words to the press since his accident and arrest, Vaughn sounded upbeat.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox first baseman Mo Vaughn launches campaign to redeem his image after his arrest last weekend on drunken driving charges (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Ken Griffey Jr. stood talking to reporters in the hubbub of the American League's All-Star locker room last summer, a young man in a Boston Red Sox uniform with a shy smile reached through to shake Griffey's hand, stated his pleasure at meeting the game's premier center fielder and asked for an autograph. Then, as if introductions were still needed, as if he, too, weren't an All-Star, the reed-thin infielder told Griffey his name was Nomar Garciaparra -- the hottest rookie in the game.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox shortstop Nomar Garciaparra is named American League Rookie of the Year; photo (M)

headline.main: Garciaparra Is Named Top Rookie in Landslide

docs.lead_paragraph: District Judge Roanne Sragow refused to throw out spousal abuse charges against the recently released Red Sox outfielder Wilfredo Cordero yesterday in Cambridge, Mass. The judge disputed a defense claim that Cordero was being selectively prosecuted because of his name. The case is scheduled to go to trial on Oct. 20.

docs.lead_paragraph: Boston Red Sox catcher MIKE STANLEY won't require surgery on his spine, the team said yesterday. Stanley, 33, underwent a repeat magnetic resonance imaging test last week, which revealed shrinkage of a herniated disc in his lower neck.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox catcher Mike Stanley will not require surgery on his spine (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Red Sox pitcher TIM WAKEFIELD was hit by a car while jogging Sunday, sustaining bruises and scrapes but no broken bones.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox pitcher Tim Wakefield is hit by car while jogging in Melbourne, Fla, sustaining bruises and scrapes (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: BUTCH HOBSON, a former manager of the Boston Red Sox, agreed yesterday to enter a program for first-time criminal offenders and will avoid jail time for a cocaine possession charge. In the settlement, Hobson acknowledged using cocaine in the past but did not admit guilt. He will be required to lecture young people about the dangers of drugs and may have to submit to drug testing and undergo counseling.

headline.main: Hobson Agrees to Enter Drug Program

docs.lead_paragraph: Mo Vaughn figures he owes his father one now. The Boston Red Sox first baseman was convinced by his father, Leroy, not to let an injury to the middle finger of his right hand force him from the 67th annual All-Star Game. That perseverance paid off today when Vaughn replaced the injured Frank Thomas in the American League's starting lineup.
